items.synopsis: Now there are calls for Queensland to follow Victoria's lead, which reduced its number of shooting deaths with a focus on de-escalation of conflict and avoiding or minimising police use of force.

title.children: Queensland Police shot 14 people last year. In Victoria, they shot one

image.altText: A header approaches the camera whilst harvesting barley

items.synopsis: China agrees to drop 80 per cent tariffs on Australian barley, after a long-running and high-profile trade war between the two nations.

title.children: China to ditch controversial Australian barley tariffs

image.altText: Neil Gaughan at a Senate Committee.

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police is forced to correct the record and clarify that Opposition Leader Peter Dutton was not briefed on the identity of a man later jailed for bribing Nauru government officials.

title.children: AFP admits Peter Dutton was not specifically briefed on concerns over Nauru businessman

image.altText: a woman holding a small child in the doorway of a burnt out home

items.synopsis: Winter temperatures have neared 40 degrees Celsius in parts of South America, which is up to 20C higher than normal for this time of year and the equivalent of Sydney hitting 35C in the first week of August.

title.children: Mid-winter temperatures in South America rival those of baking northern hemisphere summer

image.altText: A man in police uniform sits at a desk with a small microphone and nameplate in front of him.

items.synopsis: Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw rubbishes suggestions he should have declared a conflict of interest over his friendship with a senior PwC partner with whom he discussed a contract for the consulting firm.

title.children: 'No apologies': AFP commissioner rubbishes claims he should have declared friendship with PwC partner

image.altText: Fish fillets on display at market, generic image.

items.synopsis: A study of fish sold in supermarkets and restaurants around Australia finds nearly 12 per cent of seafood is mislabelled, as researchers call for more stringent labelling laws.

title.children: DNA testing shows fishy labelling of popular seafoods rife around Australia

image.altText: A woman taking a selfie

items.synopsis: A 34-year-old woman on bail for her alleged role in a 2021 murder has asked the Supreme Court to send her back to prison because of the "daily battle just trying to find suitable accommodation".

title.children: Woman on bail unable to find housing asks court to send her back to jail, judge agrees

image.altText: A court sketch depicts Donald Trump with his trademark coiffed blonde hair, blue suit and red tie, hands folded on a table

items.synopsis: Donald Trump's third indictment marks an extraordinary moment: a former president is fighting charges over his handling of the last election, while campaigning to win the next one.

title.children: Why Donald Trump’s third indictment could prove to be the most damaging

image.altText: Man in blue suit and red tie holds umbrella.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors allege Mr Trump conspired to defraud the US by preventing Congress from certifying Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.

title.children: Donald Trump pleads not guilty to 2020 election interference

image.altText: A woman dressed up and smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: The family of Gulgong schoolgirl Michelle Bright who was murdered while walking home from a party 24 years ago, say her killer took away her dreams and tore their family apart.

title.children: 'Instead of celebrating birthdays, we take flowers to the cemetery': Slain teen's family confront 'monster' killer

image.altText: An owl statue on a shelf a metre away from a live pigeon.

items.synopsis: From scarecrows to the Bunnings balcony owl, people have tried many ways to deter pesky birds. Here's why one method is causing quite a fluster.

title.children: Pigeons are having a hoot with a new bird deterrent, but residents have been left squawking

image.altText: woman smiling

items.synopsis: The parents of a 23-year-old woman who died from meningococcal B have praised today's decision to make the vaccine free and available in routine child and teen immunisation in Queensland.

title.children: It's Bella's legacy, family says, as Queensland makes meningococcal B vaccine free for children

image.altText: Aerial photo of Groote Eylandt coast line.

items.synopsis: Police say spears, crossbows and machetes have been used in the violence which involved up to 150 people on the island in the Gulf of Carpentaria.

title.children: Trio hospitalised after violent outbreak on tropical NT island

image.altText: Blue and white police tape in front of traffic accident scene

items.synopsis: Police have declared a crime scene after a person was found dead following a camper trailer fire on the Scenic Rim, west of Brisbane, this morning.

title.children: Person found dead, known resident missing after fire destroys camper trailer near Boonah

image.altText: JWST/NIRcam composite image of the Ring Nebula. The images clearly show the main ring, surrounded by a faint halo

items.synopsis: The ethereal new images provide further insight into the life cycle of stars.

title.children: 'A preview of the Sun’s distant future': James Webb telescope captures brilliant new images of dying star

image.altText: The Ares 1-X test rocket lifts off from Kennedy Space Centre

items.synopsis: Australia's space industry is warning the sector is "in limbo" and facing an uncertain future after the axing of several key space programs.

title.children: Australia's space industry 'in limbo' after key programs axed

image.altText: A huge 1970s apartment building, with white balconies, many of which feature lush gardens

items.synopsis: Vienna is often pointed to as a Western city that is getting its housing strategy right. So how do they do it?

title.children: In Vienna, most people live in social housing. Here's how it works

image.altText: Police tape surrounding an old Event cinema complex about five storeys in height.

items.synopsis: A 39-year-old man died in hospital days after he was allegedly stabbed and fell from a two-storey balcony.

title.children: Woman charged with murder after Townsville balcony fall and alleged stabbing

image.altText: COVID-19

items.synopsis: Here's a quick wrap of the COVID-19 news and case numbers from each Australian jurisdiction from the past week.

title.children: The latest COVID-19 news and case numbers from around the states and territories

image.altText: Megan Krakouer wears a shirt marking the 50th anniversary of the tent embassy

items.synopsis: Perth-based Indigenous activist Megan Krakouer switches camps in the Voice to Parliament referendum debate, saying she will now vote yes despite stridently supporting the no campaign previously.

title.children: 'Really difficult decision': Prominent campaigner against Voice set to vote yes after changing mind

image.altText: Illustration showing six B-52 bombers, stylized with American flags, flying over a map of Australia.

items.synopsis: A new US Air Force will build a "mission planning" and operations centre in Darwin, as part of $630 million in American spending across the top end over the next two to three years.

title.children: US Air Force 'mission planning' centre to be built in Northern Territory

image.altText: Suncorp accepts a $4.9 billion offer from ANZ for its banking business

items.synopsis: Australia's competition watchdog has rejected ANZ's proposed takeover of Suncorp's bank, while local traders await the RBA's latest statement on monetary policy. Follow live.

title.children: ACCC rejects ANZ's $4.9b takeover of Suncorp, Amazon earnings surge, ASX flatlines at open

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: China will lift its tariffs on Australian barley imported into the country, which have been in place since May 2020. As the government flagged earlier this week, Australia had been expecting the 80 per cent anti-dumping tariffs to be removed, with an August 11 deadline looming. Now, China's Ministry of Commerce has confirmed the news, which will come into effect tomorrow. The two countries reached an agreement to end the trade dispute back in April. It's the latest step in an improving relationship between Australia and China, with coal imports resuming in January and timber imports also back on the cards. Despite the size of the Chinese market, the steep tariffs didn't wipe out Australia barley growers, who turned to other markets. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia-China barley bust-up over after 3 years

featuredLink.title: China to ditch controversial Australian barley tariffs

children.content: China will lift its tariffs on Australian barley
imported into the country, which have been in place since May 2020.
As
the government flagged earlier this week
Australia had been expecting the 80 per cent anti-dumping tariffs to be removed
, with an August 11 deadline looming.
Now,
China's Ministry of Commerce
has confirmed the news, which will come into effect tomorrow.
The two countries reached an agreement to end the trade dispute back in April.
(ABC Great Southern: Tom Edwards)
It's the latest step in an improving relationship between Australia and China, with coal imports resuming in January and timber imports also back on the cards.
Despite the size of the Chinese market, the steep tariffs didn't wipe out Australia barley growers, who turned to other markets.
You can read more here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello from the big state - I'm popping in with an update on the price of our biggest export commodity, iron ore. It has been heading south and is now ever so close to $US100 a tonne. Take a look at this chart compiled by economists at CBA that shows the price movement since August 2020. The spot price for the commodity peaked in about May 2021 about $US240 a tonne. The price plunge links back to demand from China. Spot prices are down about 11 per cent since July 25. CBA's Mining and Energy Commodities expert, Vivek Dhar writes: "Markets are concerned that policymakers may not follow through with any meaningful support for China's commodity-intensive economy following the semi-annual economic conference attended by China's top leaders (Politburo). "The conference, which took place in late July, saw China's top leaders pledge to "strength counter cyclical policies", where an "adjustment" would be made to the restrictions on the property sector. "Policymakers even reportedly talked of bringing forward infrastructure spending to help support the economy. These announcements though lacked details such as targets and timelines ." China's property sector accounts for 35-40% of China's steel consumption. Most of China's property sector indicators have worsened through the first half of 2023. "It's challenging to see how policymakers turn-around China's property sector, particularly given the extent of supply and demand side issues that are weighing on the sector at present. "A number of factors began last year when China's COVID-zero policy crippled household balance sheets and saw a number of property developers default. "We think steel demand from China's property sector will likely only stabilise next year. "The rapid fall in iron ore prices over the last week raises downside risks to our forecast for iron ore prices to fall to $US100/t by Q4 2023. " Iron ore miners like BHP, Rio Tinto and FMG will often say they're playing the long game and don't watch spot prices, but I'm pretty sure they'll be keeping a close eye on this activity in China. It's also worth pointing out, $US100 it still much higher than the government's long term price estimates of $US55 a tonne .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Iron ore miners on alert as the commodity price nudges $US100

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Another interesting takeout from the cost of living committee was a discussion between Treasury and Senators on our housing crisis. Senator Karen Grogan began her line of questioning by asking Treasury officials whether they were concerned with housing supply and what their forecasts were for the sector, or whether it was simply house prices they were focused on. Treasury's Luke Yeaman said they keep a close eye on both the construction sector and rental market — especially the latter given it has a direct impact on inflation. He said there had been "some divergence" between medium density apartments versus standalone homes, and there had been a large surge in approvals for standalone homes because of the HomeBuilder scheme during COVID. Supply chain issues however are still having an impact on the construction sector, which is in turn affecting the housing market, because while there is a large pipeline of new housing coming online, it's much slower than expected because of those construction issues, he said. Senator Grogan asked whether Treasury expects its forecasted housing supply to be on track, to which Mr Yeaman responded that they are expecting medium density housing to alleviate pressure in the market in the next 12 to 18 months, especially with strong growth in migration. Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Housing, Kerren Crosthwaite, followed up Mr Yeaman by saying they expect some easing in the rental market when more social and affordable housing is built. Ms Crosthwaite said currently there are more people in the private rental market because there has been a reduction in available public housing. She said between 2011 and 2022, there was a reduction in social housing from 4.8% to 4.1%, which came back to state and local governments across the jurisdictions and their respective decisions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasury expects some housing market pressure to ease in next 18 months

children.content: Another interesting takeout from the cost of living committee was a discussion between Treasury and Senators on our housing crisis.
Senator Karen Grogan
began her line of questioning by asking
Treasury officials whether they were concerned with housing supply and what their forecasts were for the sector, or whether it was simply house prices they were focused on.
Treasury's
Luke Yeaman
said they keep a close eye on both the construction sector and rental market — especially the latter given it has a direct impact on inflation.
He said there had been "some divergence" between medium density apartments versus standalone homes, and there had been
a large surge in approvals for standalone homes because of the HomeBuilder scheme
during COVID.
Supply chain issues however are still having an impact on the construction sector, which is in turn affecting the housing market, because
while there is a large pipeline of new housing coming online, it's much slower than expected because of those construction issues
, he said.
Senator Grogan asked whether Treasury expects its forecasted housing supply to be on track, to which Mr Yeaman responded that they are
expecting medium density housing to alleviate pressure in the market in the next 12 to 18 months
, especially with strong growth in migration.
Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Housing,
Kerren Crosthwaite,
followed up Mr Yeaman by saying they expect some
easing in the rental market when more social and affordable housing is built
Ms Crosthwaite said currently there are
more people in the private rental market because there has been a reduction in available public housing
She said between 2011 and 2022, there was a
reduction in social housing from 4.8% to 4.1%
, which came back to state and local governments across the jurisdictions and their respective decisions.
